Posted: August 16, 2015
												Summary: From Dust is an excellent gaming experiment of sorts that cycles back on itself with its brief yet enjoyable campagin.  You play the rold of a god-esque figure that controls the elements and minimally commands your tribe to do tasks (just some simple "go here and go there".  The gameplay is fairly simple at the core though in later levels there is more thinking and fast adjusting/reacting required to ensure the tribes survival.  The learning curve is fairly steady as it adds elements or powers into the mix but I will say near the last level is a bit of a jump in dificulty compared to previous levels.   Graphics:  This game came out 4 years ago from writing this (Aug 17, 2011) and the charm and style still holds up strong.  The dynamic effects are convincing and the character design is interesting.  I do wish they had more animals that appeared to diversify the map but since this is a fairly minimalist game it works as is.  Ocasionally the tsunami effect would catch my attention because of a steap drop off or rise in the water that looked bizarre like a wall of water instead a wave but it is what it is.  Gameplay: Simple and intuitive (played with a xbox 360 controller-needed to be enabled in settings each time)  mainly you are just picking up and putting down materials (sand, water or lava, ocasionally plants or totems as well)  The game is a lightly guided sandbox of sorts where you sculpt the land by changing the flow of rivers and lava flows in order to help a tribe of people reach the exit to the level, this must be unlocked by building all of the villiages on the map which are placed on totem locations.  The level design is spot on with these totems being placed in locations that require you to use different elements and tasks to navigate your tribe but the downside is the AI for these tribe members sometimes cripples gameplay.  I encountered them all to offten crying for help because they weren't satisfied with a path to take or a height difference near them requiring some extra sand raising or lowering until satisfaction.   These poor tribesmen (and women) would also freeze up in terror next to flowing water or lava instead of trying to avoid it which often lead to their demise.Story:There isn't a strong narrative here, essentially the tribe is wondering through different areas/realms with the story cycling back on itself toward the ened.  I will give them kudos for making it work though since the focus here really is just the sandbox gameplay and the minimal aproach they took works fine.  Note:Many slam this game for Uplay issues, I don't think this is fair because Uplay isn't the game.  I am not a fan of running through steam to run through Uplay but it just is what it is, the artists and creatives that shelled out heart and soul into this game created something worth experiencing so don't let the game industry politics soil it for you.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I FIXED IT!To everyone that keeps saying that Uplay crashes and that you can't play this is what you need to do:1) Uninstall the game and Uplay (AKA Ubisoft Launcher)2) Install Uplay from Ubisoft's site.3) Login with your account (on Uplay) and make sure you're online.3.1) There is an option to activate game, choose it.3.2) Copy the game's activation code to it (the one Steam provides you)3.3) It will ask you if you want to activate From Dust to that account, choose yes.4) In Uplay, choose "Go Offline", and that's it (but don't close Uplay).6) Install the game on Steam and playNote: In Uplay's settings I recommend that you choose "Always start Offline" and disable any synchronization to Uplay (specially the save files), because it is absolute garbage, you should also disable overlay.For those wondering, the problem is the interaction between Steam and Uplay, and the fix is launching (and installing) Uplay by itself instead of letting Steam do it.The game itself is a lot of fun, it sucks that Ubisoft had to ruin it, I would recommend the game, but not the company.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												I think its a little unfair to judge this game simply by the shortcomings of Ubisoft and their terrible DRM. This game is wonderful.Thankfully someone here in the review section has gracefully provided a very useful guide on how to get the ungodliness that is UPlay to work.So, I'm not even going to talk about that. It is what it is. I never had any problems with it.From Dust on the other hand, is actually an insanely addictive game. My only wish is that it was longer. I absolutely love the combination of simulation god-game and the challenges you are given to overcome. Every time I put this game down, I consistently had the nagging urge to play it more.You can play the game however you like, whether you want to speed through the challenges or take your time unlocking everything (the extra challenge mode levels are unlocked by various things like finding totems on the landscapes or getting 100% vegetation on the current land). The game is a challenge, but there is no time limit for completing the levels and you can take your time if needed. Its actually fairly relaxing. The extra challenge levels you unlock are fun also.The nature simulations are very fun to play with and it controls very well. The controls themselves are very easy to use. I recommend playing this game with a gamepad. (I use the xbox 360 gamepad for windows.) And yes, this game is absolutely gorgeous to look at. The music, the sounds; everything is wonderful. The simulations in this game - the water and volcanoes expecially - are really amazing and fun to manipulate. Its not very long, I completed the main story in about 9 hours, but its a very nice, satisfying experience all in all. I think I may play it over again, and see if I can complete the challenges using different methods. It doesnt seem like any two playthroughs of this game will be the same. I still have many extra challenge levels complete too (there are lots of them).Dont disregard this game simply because the DRM is bad. If you can put up with the bit of extra effort it takes to get UPlay running, I promise this game is worth it.

Posted: August 17, 2011
												From Dust is a prime example of a great game ruined by a terrible publisher. Ubisoft has continued on their quest to show the world how little they care about PC gamers and From Dust is one of their worst showings yet. Another huge flaw is the lack of mouse sensitivity option, causing you to have to manually go into your mouse settings and change your sensitivity just to be able to play the game (and of course you also have to change it back when you finish). The only plus I can think of is that the game is reasonably priced (15) though I highly suggest to not buy it, the developers have already been paid and giving Ubisoft your money only influences them to continue abusing PC gamers.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Though I only have some 22 hours in on this game it's still one of my all time favorites. It is challenging at times, but also greatly amusing taking sand for instance until there's only rock left underneath then depositing it somewhere else maybe to change the flow of a river or taking water and dumpinjg it somewhere then watching it splash and flow as real water would. This game is very unique in that I've never played another game like it. The graphics are gorgeous as are the effects.My only complaints is that there isnt a sandbox mode(or at least wasnt the last time I played) which I think would be more entertaining than levels with an end goal. I also think it would be cool if they would have more of a society or city building aspect that you would then have to protect from the elements (There are villagers you have to protect, but their society doesnt develop much past small villages). Finally I'll say that while I like this game I would definitely wait until it's on sale because while it is worth buying it's not worth $15 especially considering I got frustrated with it after 22 hours ($15 dollars to me should give a person at least 96 hours worth). Though if you like a challenging game that will get you frustrated to the point where you have to take a break (like old school games from when I was a kid) only to come back with a new strategy and beat the level then you'll like this game. I personally prefer more relaxing, less challenging games, but there simply isnt any other game like this.Still it's a great game if you're a connoisseur!

Posted: December 3, 2014
												From Dust is an entertaining game that stands out from similar civilization-type games in that you have to craft the land to assist and protect your native people as they go from increasingly inhospitable locations in an effort to find their Ancients who created their world. The story is basic (and not the focus of the game) and there are no real characters besides your virtually identical-looking natives and the only narrative is that which you hear at the begining of each stage. However the voice-over does stand out as it is spoken in a Bahasa Indonesian language that is neat to listen to and don't worry, there are subtitles in English.The real fun comes from the gameplay where you gather up sand, lava, water and more in an effort to keep your people alive and help them to build and maintain their villages in ridiculously dangerous environments such as within the crater of an active volcano, hot damn! These scenarios can defintely be challenging as you will be forced to stop and think in order to plan the best course of terrain alteration or disaster will befall your villagers and you'll be forced to re-examine your strategy or even re-start the stage.I also have to point out the level of realism attached to the various elements in that lava flows like you'd expect, water from tsunamis flows down from elevated portions of the land to pool in recesses, etc. Thanks to this you'll really feel like you're crafting a believable world and perhaps even learn to appreciate how difficult it must be for certain people (both past and present) to struggle against the elements.8/10

Posted: May 22, 2013
												From Dust (  ) was on sale on Steam the other day and it looked interesting enough to pick up for $5 and so far I’m really enjoying the chance to play around with dirt and water without getting gunk under my nails.Some levels have you rushing to accomplish things in a hurry under a time limit, but most (so far) seem to allow one to play around at one’s leisure. I love making rivers and helping the plants grow across the maps. The tribal lore is interesting too, I rather like the tales of the plants and animals.On the down side, the levels load before the dramatic entry music finishes, creating a jarring moment where it should have been a nice fanfare entry, and one can’t interact much with the tribespeople. I’m wondering if the loading time music cutoff is because I've got it installed on an SSD and it might behave better on a traditional (slower-loading) platter drive.These are relatively minor though. It’s really about playing with the landscape like a helpful, mysterious deity. If you, like me, enjoyed spending hours playing with dirt and water as a child, you might rather dig From Dust.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												This game is easily a good time killer but watch out for losing site of your priorities having fun with the sand and water mechanics. I spent a lot of time making pools and lakes and making them drain from one place to another for pure entertainment even though it was not my objective. Basically you have to get your tribe memembers  from point to another to create small villages, make sure the land becomes lush with greens, and finally getting them safely to an exit. You use your powers as a god to take control of the elements to change the very shape of the land your tibe member are currently inhabiting. Pick up and drop sand to make a crude land bridge or drop water on some vegitation which has caught fire due to the constant lava flow from an active volcano or have your tribe members grab totems to protect you from raging a tsunami. There are intricate ways the game dev make use the landscape and element mechanics to insure getting your tribe memembers to saftey will not be easy.

Posted: October 7, 2011
												From Dust is somewhat of a god game. You play as invisible force of nature that goes around sucking up things like sand and water which you can then re-distribute as you please. The object of this game is to save the village people from things like tsunamis and volcanic eruptions. After you save the village people, you must safely guide them to a totem, which they dance around for a bit, magically creating another village which you'll have to protect as well. I say "somewhat of a god game" because for a "god game", your powers are very limited and initially very cool, but as you dive deeper into the games mechanics, you'll wonder what is so god-like about your character. This is a game you will either love or hate. Keep in mind, there is NO GRAPHIC SETTINGS MENU in this game. You can't change the texture quality or shaders or anything of that sort. If your computer isn't very good. Stay away from this one. Fans of this genre will love this game, while others may not.

Posted: August 19, 2011
												This game is honestly really cool. The campaign takes you through the journey of the people that lost the knowledge of their ancestors. It's very fun creating your own islands out of nothing. The game also has a very intelligent environmental system. Rivers will carry sediment down stream and expand the land, lava will steadily flow from erupting volcanos and cool to create rock. You can also change the weather! If you add too much water at a very high altitude, it will actually start to rain! This game does a very good job at creating the ultimate living sandbox. I'd recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: December 3, 2014
												From Dust is an entertaining game that stands out from similar civilization-type games in that you have to craft the land to assist and protect your native people as they go from increasingly inhospitable locations in an effort to find their Ancients who created their world. The story is basic (and not the focus of the game) and there are no real characters besides your virtually identical-looking natives and the only narrative is that which you hear at the begining of each stage. However the voice-over does stand out as it is spoken in a Bahasa Indonesian language that is neat to listen to and don't worry, there are subtitles in English.The real fun comes from the gameplay where you gather up sand, lava, water and more in an effort to keep your people alive and help them to build and maintain their villages in ridiculously dangerous environments such as within the crater of an active volcano, hot damn! These scenarios can defintely be challenging as you will be forced to stop and think in order to plan the best course of terrain alteration or disaster will befall your villagers and you'll be forced to re-examine your strategy or even re-start the stage.I also have to point out the level of realism attached to the various elements in that lava flows like you'd expect, water from tsunamis flows down from elevated portions of the land to pool in recesses, etc. Thanks to this you'll really feel like you're crafting a believable world and perhaps even learn to appreciate how difficult it must be for certain people (both past and present) to struggle against the elements.8/10

Posted: August 17, 2014
												God Games have always been one which you've have the overall power the wield the world at your fingertips, with each God Game type having their own different style to give, showing the emphasis of what type of god you are in that specific universe. Sometimes the wielding of nature (which is most common in god games) is used to a much greater advantage, one of which provides the player to have much more strategy that simply clicking on the environment. From Dust perfectly does this. From Dust developed by Ubisoft is a game where you play as a deity which has the power to shift the lands underneath the native people's feet for their own means of survival. From Dust's story synopsis is about a group of native in which their land is torn by the natural causes, until they summon their god (the player) to help them strive to a new land in which they may find a peaceful location to settle on with any nature causes harming their colony. The Story is told through a more native style tale which help give a more tribal and authentic feel to the games' art style, with such a story it can be consider to have contain a hidden message or parable. (Though I'll overlook that)The gameplay is pretty much like other god games. You have to move around the natural element of the world to help suit the needs of the native people, to get from point A to B, which 'B' is a tunnel to the next level. The native people set up camp near a tribal totem pole in which it gives you various additional power to prevent natural disasters or pave way to an exit. This is the games' strongest point: the powers that the player has. The game makes it clear that you can grab and bend the natural element to your will. Ubisoft was clever with this technique as each level gives a limited amount of supply of a certain element. This is to make you strategise the current situation and makes you focus on rationing certain elements. Sometimes they give too much of an element and its up to the player to prevent that specific element destroy the tribes people. Sometimes this can done through kites which give special powers prevent certain elements from destroying the tribe. The art style of the game is somewhat unique, in that it uses more tribal colours and texture which exist in more tropical environments, like Hawaii and Togo. The graphics are technically well designed with very little glitches or flaws that exist within the game. The flaws that exist within the game are the sometimes unfairness of a certain level, elements attacking the tribe too quickly and giving a game over. Another is the AI which has a lack of pathfinding when going to a location which is perfect valid with no obstacles in the way. Last but not least is the somewhat lack of a sandbox mode or more time to use your creative skill in building nature constructs. Personally I had a great time using some elements to create damns and bridges, changing the flows of certain elements is what is highly enriching besides the strategy element of the game.Overall From Dust is a great game which I highly recommend to anyone who loves God Games and want a bit more strategy as well. 7.75/10.0 (Very Good)

Posted: January 31, 2015
												Beautiful little game that's got some fantastic mechanics here. The only problems are Uplay and the length. I believe the problems with Uplay that meant that this game couldn't be launched have now been fixed (at least, I've never had any issues since I bought it), so that's something.The gameplay is essentially a puzzle-based god game, where you control the elements earth, lava and water and are able to give basic directions to a handful of villagers in order to help your tribe survive. Levels generally focus on one or two problems building up - an incoming flood, or an impending volcanic eruption - and require you to take action to protect your village from the same.The game is, though, far too short. It feels more like a tutorial campaign. What little is there is very nice, with great music and atmosphere. If in future the mechanic is expanded upon, that's something I'd definitely pick up. For now, this is a great game that's on sale often enough, and is definitely worth a shot when it's at about half the asking price.

												From Dust delivers excellent gameplay that's easy to learn yet amazingly addictive, making it one of the best simulators out there. The story itself shows that the developers did their research, keeping things simple while showcasing the characters' cultural development. The main story has thirteen levels with an ending that fits; this seeming brevity is more than made up for by replay value and the challenge mode's sheer variety of levels. Thinking is definitely required for this game, as is good timing. Remember: it's okay to restart a level if you feel like you made a mistake - that's why the restart option is there.

Posted: August 20, 2011
												Ever since Black&White, I have waited for a new game where you get to be a god. I mean, who doesn't want to be the one who controls mother nature? The game gets off at an easy start, to get you comfortable in controlling, how to shape the nature. For example, by making a new path over a river by dropping sand. Throughout the game, you get to help these "citizens"... (or whatever you wanna call it) ...to build villages. But in order for them to survive, you need to control and keep an eye on the nature, so they won't get killed by, for example, a flood.As you move on in the game, you get to control more and more elements of the nature, as the missions allso gets even harder.In the long run, this game is awesome! You get to be a god, with small people who rely on YOU to keep them safe on their journey.Downsides:There's only one (1) cinematic, that you get to see between every new mission/map.The camera view controls could be more sensitive.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												From Dust is a gorgeous game with an interesting concept of playing god and encouraging the growth of your tribe as it recovers its memories and re-establishes itself.  The controls are a bit difficult to get a grasp on at first but are easy to use once you have the hang of it.  The game itself is visually stunning with detailed shots of the landscape and your tribe.  However, the game has been difficult to play for longer than bursts of ten or fifteen minutes without those same beautiful visuals slowing and eventually freezing my computer until the game shuts down or has to reboot.  My computer has never had these kinds of problems with games before and I am usually patient enough that if I can get a good amount of play time in then I don't mind.  From Dust, however, shuts down too frequently to really do much in a playing session.

												This game is a great experience, I think that's what it is.It's not the game of the year. But it's really something new, the control scheme is a bit akward, sometimes you have to play with your camera a lot because YOU ARE and your camera is tied to you. So yeah it can be slightly frustrating in a couple of levels however it's all part of the design.This game is not difficult at all, this game is a refreshing experience, a new way to see god games. Posted: January 13, 2014
												From Dust is a god game, but not in the way that you might think. Instead of leading a civilization into expansion, you're instead trying to guide them through the world, "fighting" against the forces of nature themselves.Tech-wise, the game looks gorgeous, and more importantly has this fantastic physics system in which fluid and dust settle realistically. This is important, because those are what you'll manipulate most of the time, be it to open a path, to let forest spread, to stop fires, whatever is needed. It's an experience unlike any other game out there.However, as much as I like it, I have to say that it's best to pick up the console versions. For a very simple reason, the PC one brings the uPlay DRM, a highly incompetent piece of software developed by Ubi that has a 50/50 chance of denying you the game you just bought. Myself, I had to spend just under an hour tinkering and watching "update" bars fill up before the game worked. Even if it was worth the trouble in the end, this sort of abuse with your honest customers is simply ridiculous.If you do want to pick it up on PC anyways, good luck, and have a pad ready. K&M controls here are a love-or-hate thing, and you might want to try both out to see which suits you better.

Posted: June 3, 2013
												One of my all-time favourite games. Buy it buy it buy it.+ Gorgeous looking, slow and mesmerising. If you like god games this is one of the simplest and best... no numbers, no birth rate charts, no 'we require more food!' You are a spirit that can pick up earth, water and lava. Using these you must guide a tribe across a dozen levels that are basically physics/logic puzzles wrapped in a stunning 3d terrain simulator. Rivers wash earth downstream and create deltas, lava hits the sea and cools into rock. Like I said, mesmerising. Nothing quite like it.- Essentially a sexed-up tech demo for the terrain engine, not bad in itself but this is definitely not a full-sized game. Leaves you wanting more.- There is a bolted-on challenge mode that offers exactly zero fun.- All the levels are slow-paced and easy once you know what to do... except two that require decent planning and very good timing. Again not bad in itself, just a bit of an awkward step up from the laidback gameplay of previous levels.

Posted: December 25, 2012
												Ever wonder if nature was ever in your grasp? how about within your control?Go back to ancient times once more to discover a lost civilization capable of moving lava, raising tides, planting plants (I know sounds ridiculous), and makeing land. Sounds fun right? Being able to be god and create nature with your grasp. Here's the catch, before your god your weak. A Pathetic little, nearly insignificant person who can't even control nature. So in order to become a so-called-god. (At least I think I was a god).One must verge onwards!Through raging tides!Mountainous volcano's!Unforgiving Floods!Horrifying Fires!Honestly, the dust at my shoes accumulated so much I find it so unappealling. But for this game. I highly enjoyed it, it offered a breath of new originality, gameplay, and most of all ingenuity. The story would be average at best, if you're looking for a small time get-a-way from AAA titles. I'd highly recommend this game to anyone seeking a new life, from the seriuos pace of high rated games. And just for kicks out there, The Dust at my shoes originated from somewhere, it's just I forgot where. Although... the game does provide a good measure of mental working through the brain into working out it's kinks (if you know what I mean). I wouldn't coonsider them really puzzles, like that of Portal, but it provides the brain with yet another mental work, that should at least be enjoyable to any Dusty New-comers.From Sea to Land to Fire and now Dust...7.4/10

Posted: August 18, 2011
												From Dust is a very neat puzzle/simulation game where you manipulate earth, lava, and water to shape the land, making it livable for the tribe you're protecting.The engine driving this game is really neat. As you tame the wilderness, rivers will change paths, hills will erode, and the lava shapes new land. It's definitely fun to play with, and it's very rewarding to see a ruthless wasteland turn into a peaceful grove once you correctly divert the hazards.This game's weak point is everything else (except the game's mythos; that's cool too). The story is way too short (beat it 100% in <3 hrs) and rather easy. With such cool tools to use, I really wanted more of the sandbox-type story levels, to really show off what I could do. Huge disappointment. There's a challenge mode, which I beat in about another 3 hours.I'd still recommend this game at $15, but be prepared for the short length. Also watch out for Ubisoft's wicked always-online DRM. Definitely get it if it's on sale.

Posted: July 16, 2013
												This game is pretty fun!You play as a godly snake-thing called ''The Breath'' summoned by tribes of little masked people to guide them through the dangers of nature and into new lands after their ''Ancients''.The language they speak in is quite charming, the story they tell is good, the AI is generally good although the path finding can be finnicky at times, and the physics are simply AMAZING.Moving around lava, water and earth is fun to do and the puzzles you solve with it are challenging, but not overly so.Lastly, the natural disasters some levels harbor and the way your tribes counter them if you did your job correctly are a sight to behold (and hear).All in all, this game is completely worth it.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												After getting the game to work, I'm changing my vote from No to Yes. Looks like the steam community bailed me out, they figured out a way to get uPlay to cooperate. Thanks guys! :) Now that I can safely say this is still working (uPlay is totally awful), I'm happy to report that this game is still as creative, beautiful and unique as it was in 2011. I've never played anything like it before or since. In fact, playing from dust when it first came out got me pretty interested in other simulation games like this, but none of them ever compared to what From Dust does. The way you manipulate water in this game is really what does it for me. The way water flows, builds up, carries dirt, interacts with lava, surges in tides, gushes from holes in mountains, it's just all so well done and fascinating. I just spent an hour on the first level, watching water from two river sources carve out an enormous landmass from nothing. This game is amazing, and it deserved far better than the treatment Ubisoft gave it. Bogging it down with uPlay basically condemned the game to a fate it didn't deserve. But it really is an amazing game. I've never seen it on sale, but for $15 you're buying a pretty unique experience. <3 So glad I got it working again!

Posted: January 24, 2012
												On paper, the concept behind From Dust is filled with promises. A simulator where you can manipulate terrains on a whim? Groundbreaking! But despite its enormous potential, this title ends up offering too little.From Dust is no more a simulator than it is a puzzle. In its (short) story mode, you are tasked with occupying totems scattered throughout several islands. Your opposition comes from the destructive forces of storms, tsunamis, and magma. Against these, you must utilize your godlike abilities to construct a safe haven.Outside the campaign are dozens of challenge maps. Here, you are given a limited set of abilities with which you'll use to accomplish an objective, be it migrating tribes or saving them from extinction.Once the campaign and challenges are completed, that's it. There is little to no reason to replay this game unless you really enjoyed it. The unreleased map editor would've gone a long way to making this a lasting title, but alas, it isn't one.Grade: B-

												This game is very weird. Totally didn't expect it. You have your little villagers that you send to one of four totems in each world.  Once all four totems are settled, you can move onto the next level. What makes it hard is the tsunamis, volcanos, flooding, and such that destroys your villages. The game is about not managing the villages themselves like a civ game, but more protecting them by redirecting the elements.It wasn't bad, but I only got a few hours out of it. If it's cheap, I'd get it. You don't get the 'free to create' sandbox by the end though, and I had enough of the game once I got there.

												This is a beautiful unique little god-mode game with a rather original concept and interesting mechanics and bit of puzzle in it. I haaaate uPay, but luckily I had no problems with it. (tip, try giving uPay administrator rights, it worked for me with windows 7 crashes, and with windows 8.1 it's been just smooth sailing with the bugger).Anyway I wish not to give a bad review to a good game because of the horrible DRM, which may have not even been the choice of the developers but forced on it by Ubisoft by default.My only grief with the game was that it was very, very short and overall small. The campaign is done through in couple hours, and then you have bunch of very short challenge scenarios (don't trust my hours I tend to leave games open in the background). It lacks longer play scenarios and depth in many things, like the frequent discoveries don't really bring anything to the table, and there is _no_ long world building and evolving sandbox mode of proper type, part from maybe repeating levels of the campaign which are quite linear whatsoever, and the last bit free build if you really, really like just sculpting scenarios for no other purpose. I find it weird it is advertised as such.I could easily see myself going for ~100 hours with this game if they had extended it and gave it bit more depth, growing possibilities and more interaction in features. Alas, now you prolly get around 10h max out of it.Considering how small the game is and not very new anymore it is a bit overpriced. However it truly was very enjoyable and I gulfed through it quickly and exitedly. Do give it a try if you have spare money, especially if it's on sale.

Posted: February 7, 2015
PRO:The primary mechanic of manipulating the land is wonderfully executed. Every level is creative and interesting and I never felt like I was just repeating the level before it. This game gets top marks for game design.Furthermore, the presentation is top notch. The water and lava flow beautifully and everything is tied together nicely with a distinct visual style.CON:The problem with this game mainly comes from the fact that it was designed for consoles and poorly adapted for PCs. The mouse vertical/horizontal axes control a little pointer that tracks the terrain rather than the screen, making it needlessly difficult to click things on uneven ground.The game is also filled with unskippable cutscenes. Between levels you repeatedly watch the same cutscene. The scene is only about 60 second longs, but it's still annoying. Also, periodically in a level the game takes control of your camera to slowly pan around the new objective, even if you've played that level before and already seen the cutscene. It breaks the flow of the game and, worse yet, the world doesn't pause for the cutscene. I've lost villages while my camera was seized from me. It's not the end of the world, but it's a ridiculous thing for a game studio to overlook.This combined with the mouse issue leaves me sorely disappointed in Ubisoft's user interface design. Do they have a QA department?There's also no real story to speak of. You just follow a tribe around different levels. The lack of story doesn't seriously detract from the game, but a quality story or just some kind of world building would have certainly added to it.SUMMARY:That said, the game is still engaging and unique. It's short*, but that's just because it's all quality content that they didn't pointlessly recycle (unlike 90% of all other games out there). If you really want more after the "story", there are challenge maps.You've probably never played a game like this before. It's worth it on that basis alone. Better still, it's actually quite engaging. This is the best game I've played from Ubisoft that I can remember.* I consider short a pro, since I don't have 100 hours to blow grinding. But I understand that other people feel differently. If you like long games, don't let this game being short dissuade you.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I FIXED IT!To everyone that keeps saying that Uplay crashes and that you can't play this is what you need to do:1) Uninstall the game and Uplay (AKA Ubisoft Launcher)2) Install Uplay from Ubisoft's site.3) Login with your account (on Uplay) and make sure you're online.3.1) There is an option to activate game, choose it.3.2) Copy the game's activation code to it (the one Steam provides you)3.3) It will ask you if you want to activate From Dust to that account, choose yes.4) In Uplay, choose "Go Offline", and that's it (but don't close Uplay).6) Install the game on Steam and playNote: In Uplay's settings I recommend that you choose "Always start Offline" and disable any synchronization to Uplay (specially the save files), because it is absolute garbage, you should also disable overlay.For those wondering, the problem is the interaction between Steam and Uplay, and the fix is launching (and installing) Uplay by itself instead of letting Steam do it.The game itself is a lot of fun, it sucks that Ubisoft had to ruin it, I would recommend the game, but not the company.

You must settle new villages next to the totems in order to unlock new powers for your avatar.  Lead your people across the land following the path of the ancients while gaining power and abilities. Non-violent and age appropriated for the entire family.

Posted: August 21, 2011
												Very innovative game. The nature effects, such as the crashing of waves on the shore, flow of water down a natural river, and flowing lava are amazing. The story mode is challenging and requires you to spend extra time on the map to fully unlock all the story/challenge 'memories'. Sadly, this suffers from bad console port syndrome, as there are some graphical anomolies, sound weirdness, cutscenes abruptly ending, and some control weirdness. The game is still very playable and lots of fun. I would've liked to see a sandbox mode, where you can start with a blank slate and just start building your own land mass and/or make your own maps to challenge friends. Definitely worth the price point. I estimate the game story mode takes about 4-5 hours to complete.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												A decent-enough game in the spirit of Black & White minus the village building (the villagers do that themselves around totems when you tell them). Each level requires you to found a village around each totem and spread vegatation for bonus materials all while dealing with whatever potential hazards the level may have. Whether that be torrential rains, tsunamis, or volcanoes or some combination thereof. Due to the initial outcry at launch, Ubi made it possible to bypass Uplay and play it offline; in updates since, they quietly edited that bypass back out again. As a result, I can't recommend the game due to them pulling something backhanded like that, let alone changing their original stance on its DRM from the original launch to begin with.

Posted: August 17, 2011
												As far as "God" simulation games go, From Dust offers a unique twist on the genre. The physics based environments and puzzles offer a great variety in gameplay, allowing you to choose how YOU want to finish the level. The graphics are lush and amazing to look at, I'll find myself just admiring the scenery sometimes rather than doing what I'm supposed to do. I would definitely reccomend it to anyone who's open to this kind of game. The only hangup I'd say there is would be that sometimes the AI doesn't quite understand that you've laid out a perfect path for them, and the oftentimes take the much more dangerous route. All in all though that's just a minor hindrance to a great game, especially for only $15!

If you can't play a game without some gruff chap on the radio going "Get your♥♥♥♥♥to the neon pink arrow scum!", don't even bother thinking about this game.The physics on the geology shaping is well done, the graphics are fantastic in places, not so great in others (Console port after all) and regardless to what the trailer may give the impression of the weather sequences are NOT cutscenes, they're realtime events going down that interact with the world as you have shaped it.Just don't go experimenting with volcanos... that often leads to everyone dead in fiery badness :\

Posted: August 18, 2011
												From Dust is a very neat puzzle/simulation game where you manipulate earth, lava, and water to shape the land, making it livable for the tribe you're protecting.The engine driving this game is really neat. As you tame the wilderness, rivers will change paths, hills will erode, and the lava shapes new land. It's definitely fun to play with, and it's very rewarding to see a ruthless wasteland turn into a peaceful grove once you correctly divert the hazards.This game's weak point is everything else (except the game's mythos; that's cool too). The story is way too short (beat it 100% in <3 hrs) and rather easy. With such cool tools to use, I really wanted more of the sandbox-type story levels, to really show off what I could do. Huge disappointment. There's a challenge mode, which I beat in about another 3 hours.I'd still recommend this game at $15, but be prepared for the short length. Also watch out for Ubisoft's wicked always-online DRM. Definitely get it if it's on sale.

Posted: June 12, 2013
												I really like the idea of this game but it has graphical and longevity issues.First off the textures are beyond bad on this game. It's like looking at a 640x480 game zoomed in to a 50'' screen, that's how bad it is, so it will be really noticeable if you look attently (fortunately you don't have to play a lot of time, it's short), that being said it's a straight up port from the consoles.The game concept is really interesting, but it's really simple, for a god game if you have almost no power at all over the world. Basically controlling the "forces of nature" (lava/water/land) around your island, e.g. building natural barriers to block tsunamis/volcano eruptions, creating bridges to block rivers.It has a simple campaign format where you play maps with an increased number of powers each, but there's not much of a change in between each, and almost no interest to move on.After a while it just gets old and tiring and the lack of good sandbox game features make it pretty stale, I'd say get it if you like the idea of the game, which is pretty much terraforming an island, but don't expect a sandbox game like black&white.

												This is a beautiful game. It's gameplay is that you direct spiritual powers that can shape the world. By shaping the world you save the villagers. Posted: August 17, 2011
												It's a very overproduced Puzzle Game, not a Simulation, not a God Game. The puzzles aren't overly complex, and in fact difficulty stems not from figuring out what to do, but actually managing to do whatever has to be done while battling against the controls and mechanics that are inaccurate and indirect at best, but had to be so the game could flaunt its all-style presentation with unfortunately little substance. It's pretty to look at, has a lot of flair and some nice extra things to find that give you a little blurb of text full of pathos, but the core game is.... well, there's very little game here, since, again, the puzzles are shallow and its all in the menial "work" of executing what you want to do. You might aswell go play darts with a friend or something, except unlike playing this Singleplayer game, there'd actually be some investment in the competition and your own performance other than simply killing time.

Posted: April 18, 2014
Changes your visionFrom Dust contains great part of the world vision used by mankind to explain its surroundings in pre-christian era: the spoken tradition. Hidden within its storyline and in the bonus tales unlocked, one is able to understand how some of our ancestors saw the world and how they believed they could control it: how their traditions of music and ritual kept their minds tranquil against the perils of natural catastrophe and wild dangers.Not only that, the game is work of art, comprising beautifully executed music, masterful narrative and astonishing visuals, all capable of arousing a sense of longing, of belonging to that ancient past.

Don't get the game if this is a deal breaker for you as you're most likely going to have DRM issues.The game mechanics are cool, and some of the maps are frustrating and then you find a way through it. It is a very short game, but the challenges are also pretty cool too. Getting the game on sale is probably a good idea.

Posted: August 24, 2011
												My recommendation is DO NOT BUY.If you didn't notice in the fine print:3rd-party DRM: Ubisoft Online ServiceThat's UPlay, Ubisoft's always-on DRM with a separate patcher (for the DRM), separate updater (for the game) and separate account and login. I haven't managed to get to the actual game part yet thanks to all the Ubisoft crud and hoops they want you to jump through before they will allow you to load the game.(And yes, you will see three separate "Now patching..." prompts with progress bars before you get to the UPlay login screen.)As a side note, the UPlay username "WhyDoIHaveToDoThis?" is already taken. So are "WhyGodWhy", "WhyDoIBother", "UbisoftAreIdiots", "UPlayIsStupid", and "KillMeNow". At that point I got bored and mashed the keyboard. So look me up, I'm sazwethiujolk on UPlay. (Also, UPlay requires your birth date but limits it to an earliest year of 1910, requiring those of us born before that date to lie in answer to the question.)

Posted: November 11, 2016
												This game is a technological masterpiecePart Black & White, part work of artYou play as a Godlike figure, guiding your people from one end of the map to the other, while avoiding natural disasters by manipulating the physical environment by essentially terraforming what you canShort, but sweet, and does not offer much replay value but I did enjoy playing through it a second time a few years later.If you're a fan of Godgames, and like the sound of manipulating the physical environment in order to help save people from their ultimate demise on their way to some "promised" land, give this game a try!

Posted: November 13, 2016
												A really enjoyable little game. One of the few where it's worthwhile making it to the final level.Playing with the tools on offer in the game is very relaxing and calming...  the kind of geography creation that will keep you up till the early hours. 8/10 - lost 2 whole points for not having a pure creation mode. ***Spoiler***: The last level is basically a creation tool... but it's not truely free form and you have to have the villages... which I'd very much like to leave out!

Posted: January 9
												If you like Black & White, this is the next best thing. Its more of a puzzle game with some god game elements. It's short. VERY short. You finish it in a day or two. I would recomend it, but the Uplay BS you have to go to is not fun and takes a long time. If you didn't have already a Uplay account , you'll have to make one, then do a two-step verification. It's a little too much hassle to play a game that would take a few days to finish.

Posted: April 13
												Ya know, I struggled for a while to get this game to play on my computer.In the end, it ended up logging 10 hours of my time before I realised, the ads for the game were moreentertaining to me than the game play.Such a shame.

Posted: August 27, 2012
												Nice little sandbox that is good to idle away a few hours. In story mode you lead your tribe through a number of terrains trying to populate totems, which grant certain powers and which you need to complete the level. Once you got all the totems, you can continue to the next level. There really isnt a story as such though, but sust some cutscenes (which you cannot skip) with some esoteric blah blah. There is also a challenge mode in which you have to reach certain objectives which I found rather boring. But still, worthwhile enough to buy.
